item.title: Conditionals
item.description:
Course description

These lectures will introduce the philosophical discussion about conditionals. For this, we need to ask what the relation is between the meaning of formal languages and the meaning of natural languages.

Online resources

Outlines and handouts will be made available on:

http://msteenhagen.github.io/teaching/2018cda/

Where and when

Monday 3-4pm. Lecture Block Room 1.

Lecture 1: Meaning and natural language

This lecture will discuss Grice’s theory of sentence meaning and communicative intentions.

(Download handout here)

Suggested reading

H.P. Grice (1957), ‘Meaning’, The Philosophical Review, Vol. 66, No. 3. (Jul., 1957), pp. 377-388.

Lecture 2: Logic and conversation

This lecture will expand on Grice’s theory of sentence meaning, by considering the role and behaviour of conventional and conversational implicature.

(Download handout here)

Suggested reading

H. P. Grice (1957), ‘Logic and Conversation’ in Peter Cole and Jerry L. Morgan (eds.) Syntax and Semantics, Vol. 3, Speech Acts, New York: Academic Press 1975 (Also in Grice’s Studies in the Ways of Words)

Lecture 3: Paradoxes of natural language

This lecture will introduce the paradoxes of conditionals, which occur when we try to transition between natural and formal languages. We will try to resolve these paradoxes by using Grice’s theory of implicature.

(Download handout here)

Suggested reading

Mark Sainsbury (2001), ‘The Project of Formalization,’ (ch. 6) in Logical Forms: An Introduction to Philosophical Logic, Oxford: Blackwell, 339-391.

Lecture 4: Conditionals: two approaches approaches

In this lecture we will look at problems with the Gricean solution to the paradoxes of conditionals, and consider an alternative approach

(Download handout here)

Suggested reading

Dorothy Edgington (2008), ‘Conditionals’, in E.N. Zalta, ed., Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy (Winter Edition) [Online].

item.title: Induction and Causation
item.description:
Course description

These lectures will introduce the problems of induction and the metaphysics of causation (or causality, or cause and effect).

Online resources

Outlines and handouts will be made available on:

http://msteenhagen.github.io/teaching/2018inc/

Where and when

Friday 10-11. Lecture Block Room 1.

Lecture 1: Hume and the problem of induction

In this lecture I introduce the idea of induction, and discuss David Hume’s problem of induction.

(Download handout here)

Lecture 2: Goodman’s new riddle of induction

In this lecture I discuss Nelson Goodman’s ‘new riddle’ of induction, and will contrast it with the old riddle formulated by David Hume.

(Download handout here)

Lecture 3: Causes and regularities

In this lecture I introduce David Hume’s sceptical approach to causation, and show how it has led the way for regularity theories of causation. There are some problems with such theories. In particular, regularity theories seem to have little to say about the particular events that seem to be fundamental to causal interaction.

J.L. Mackie offers an analysis that identifies these particular events as special conditions: INUS conditions. His suggestion is that something is a cause if it is at least an INUS condition for an effect. I close by discussing three problems with Mackie’s theory.

(Download handout here)

Lecture 4: Counterfactual theories

In this lecture I introduce David Lewis’ framework for thinking about counterfactual conditionals, and show how he applies this framework to a theory of causation. Causal dependence is a relation between distinct events that is defined in terms of counterfactual dependence relations between statements about these events’ occurrence (or absence thereof).

The counterfactual theory gives rise to question baout the asymmetry and transitivity of causation, and does not always deal well with cases of overdetermination and pre-emption.

(Download handout here)
